subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: Anthony, Thank you for putting this together. I had been working on a mapping for my own accent (West Coast US) between QS and the CMU phoneme set, but I
messageBody:
Anthony,

Thank you for putting this together. I had been working on a mapping
for my own accent (West Coast US) between QS and the CMU phoneme set,
but I hadn't been able to resolve how I should handle the NORTH and
FORCE lexical sets. It feels quite unnatural for me to use anything
other than #38 for both, so now I will follow your chart and abandon
my attempt to train myself to use the ligature #33+#25 for these sets.

I wouldn't have put SQUARE and DRESS together, myself. I would have
assigned DRESS to #28 and SQUARE to #29. For SQUARE I'm perfectly
happy with the ligature #29+#25. Am I alone in this?

Thanks.

Ted


On Nov 5, 2007 5:14 AM, Anthony Grahn <othermale@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> I was about to ask in response:
>
> "When merging BATH with TRAP why did we choose #30 At for the
> combined set rather than #32 Ah?"
>
> But I decided to be more proactive and explicitly draw an outline
> lexical sets use with QS. Perhaps the outline below is what you had in
> mind.
>
> Some QS letters have lexical sets assigned to them permanently and
> everyone must use that letter for that lexical set no matter its sound
> it. Period.
>
> *But* some lexical sets may be assigned to different letters
> depending on the speaker's accent.
>
> In the following figure, lexical sets named in black can not be
> moved but those named in gray can have any one of the positions it is
> written in.
> A given Anglophone then takes this template chart and moves all the
> gray lexical sets to black lexical sets that match the sound.
>
> (Fig 1)
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/fig1.jpg
>
> When an RP speaker does this he gets
>
> (Fig 2)
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/fig2.jpg
>
> When a west coast speaker does this he gets
>
> (Fig 3)
> http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/files/Pronunciation/fig3.jpg
>
>
> Issue 1:
> Exactly which lexical sets should be frozen to a particular QS
> letter and which should be allowed to move? The images I made above
> for Fig 1. is certainly totally inadequate and is really only usable
> for a couple accents. Far more lexical sets would have to be able to
> move to other letters. But too many is a very big problem (see next issue)
>
> Issue 2:
> There can not be some many "re-assignable" lexical sets that a given
> accent can arrange the chart in more than one way. If this were
> possible, people with the same accent would use different letters in
> spelling the same word. Each *person* maybe consistent but within the
> accent there would be wide variation.
>
> Issue 3:
> Complexity: Lexical set use is going to be harder to explain than a
> static IPA map. I am already completely glossing over how Roe will
> work with lexical sets or how we explain how to assign the set CURE
> with its "invisible" consonantal y.
>
> Issue 4:
> Internal consistency: can one coherently integrate Roe into every
> possible arrangement of lexical sets with letters? If so can this be
> described sufficiently simply?
>
> Issue 5:
> Does it solve any problems? eg Readability of Australian text. I'm
> perfectly willing to admit there may be a problem here but as I see
> evidence to the contrary, I just want to see evidence that it's true.
> Notice that when I assign an IPA value to each letter, it is
> virtually the same as Read would, the exception being a slight change
> for #36.
> It's said however that after such an exercise, an Australian would
> put IPA values entirely different than Read under every QS letter. It
> would be nice to try this exercise and find out. If everyone produces
> the same or similar IPA mapping after such an excursive then lexical
> sets are not necessary and we can just assign those IPA values.
> If and only if radically different IPA values emerge from the
> excursive then the issue raised about readability needs to be
> addressed. Even in such a case I do not think there would be a problem
> but I could easily be wrong, I just want empirical confirmation before
> committing.
> Lexical sets are going to be a lot harder to explain than a static
> IPA map so we want to make sure we get something for the extra cost.
> If lexical sets solve a readability issue (if there is one) then it is
> significantly better then a fixed IPA mapping and I am all for it.
>
>
>

Anthony,

Thank you for putting this together. I had been working on a mapping
for my own accent (West Coast US) between QS and the CMU phoneme set,
but I hadn't been able to resolve how I should handle the NORTH and
FORCE lexical sets. It feels quite unnatural for me to use anything

I wouldn't have put SQUARE and DRESS together, myself. I would have
assigned DRESS to #28 and SQUARE to #29. For SQUARE I'm perfectly
happy with the ligature #29+#25. Am I alone in this?

Thanks.

Ted
